title: Oracle on Track to Acquire NetSuite, a Cloud Storage Company
abstract: The company said that holders of 53 percent of unaffiliated NetSuite shares agreed to tender their shares, and the deal will be completed on Monday.

title: Volkswagen Emissions Scandal Inquiry Widens to Top Levels
abstract: Prosecutors are investigating whether Hans Dieter Pötsch, the carmaker’s former top finance official, failed to warn shareholders about the scandal.

title: A Lawyer With a Taste for Soy Sauce and a High Tolerance for Pain
abstract: Although Jonathan Blum had spent his legal career advising businesses, turning his passion into a company wasn’t as straightforward as he had expected.

title: How LinkedIn Drove a Wedge Between Microsoft and Salesforce
abstract: Once so close they flirted with a merger, the software giants became archrivals when they realized the value of the data amassed by social networks.

title: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Gaming as Prophylaxis to Elections
abstract: Mike is a medieval witch hunter, as Farhad retreats into Mario. Microsoft’s grab for Slack’s lunch is discussed. And Amazon could do better at inspiring shopping.

title: The Money Management Gospel of Yale’s Endowment Guru
abstract: The mammoth Yale endowment fund run by David Swensen has been a training ground for investment managers, its alumni now scattered through the nonprofit world.

title: New Item on the College Admission Checklist: LinkedIn Profile
abstract: Social media experts are advising high school seniors to create professional profiles on LinkedIn and draw them to the attention of college admissions officers.

title: Bill Simmons’s HBO Program Is Canceled
abstract: HBO was eager to tap Mr. Simmons’s base of readers of his sports column, but that audience failed to materialize.

title: Wall St. Scion Gets 4 Years in Prison for Fraud
abstract: Andrew Caspersen, a Wall Street executive from a well-off family, received a far shorter sentence than prosecutors sought after a doctor testified he had a gambling addiction.

title: Tesla’s Bid for SolarCity Gets Support From Shareholder Adviser
abstract: The backing of Institutional Shareholder Services could sway Tesla shareholders because the firm’s recommendations carry great weight among mutual funds.

title: Direct Relief Donation Page
abstract: Direct Relief's new online donor site.

title: Competition Would Be the Best Solution to Rising Drug Prices
abstract: Prosecutors are investigating drug makers for colluding over prices, but higher consumer costs may be a natural consequence of reduced competition.

title: Samsung, Stung by Galaxy Note Failure, Recalls Washing Machines
abstract: A recall of 2.8 million washing machines in the United States exceeds the 1.9 million Galaxy Note smartphones recalled last month.

title: A Formula for Easier-to-Read Excel Work Sheets
abstract: Adding color or a shade of gray to every other row in your spreadsheet can help your eyes focus better on the information.

title: Daily Report: Vote Hacking
abstract: With four days to go to the elections, the possibility of hackers prancing into the voting mechanisms is foremost on federal and state officials’ minds.

title: Rolling Stone Loses Defamation Case Over Rape Story
abstract: A jury found liability on the part of the magazine, its parent company and the author of the article.

title: How to Satirize This Election? Even the Onion Is Having Trouble
abstract: The 2016 presidential campaign, with its unsavory issues and unpopular candidates, has proved challenging to the staff of the satirical website The Onion.

title: Wall St. Ends Lower, Extending a Losing Streak
abstract: Despite the government’s encouraging jobs report, the S.&P. 500 closed lower for a ninth straight day, the longest losing streak in 36 years.

title: Deirdre Quinn: If a Meeting Starts at 9, Be There at 8
abstract: Ms. Quinn, chief of the women’s fashion site Lafayette 148 New York, says her pet peeve is lateness. When a meeting starts, she says, she closes the door.

title: Morning Agenda: Wells Fargo, Washington and Wall Street, Pharma Price-Fixing
abstract: In the latest accusations to hit Wells Fargo, former employees say the bank used termination notices to retaliate against attempts to blow the whistle on its fraudulent activities.

title: Last Economic Snapshot Before the Election Shows Healthy Job Growth
abstract: While the presidential campaigns have been preoccupied with issues beyond the economy, the report refocuses attention on the crucial issue of jobs.

title: Dick Clark Productions to Be Sold to Chinese Company for $1 Billion
abstract: The sale to Dalian Wanda, which has been on a buying spree, would include broadcasting rights to the Golden Globes and other TV spectacles.

title: ‘We Almost Have Riots’: Tensions Flare in Silicon Valley Over Growth
abstract: As the region has become more congested and expensive, there are growing demands to rein in the physical space that many technologists call home.

title: E. Lee Hennessee, a Leading Woman in Hedge Funds, Dies at 64
abstract: Ms. Hennessee created one of the first indexes to track the hedge fund industry’s secretive transactions.

title: News of Charges in Price-Fixing Inquiry Sends Pharmaceuticals Tumbling
abstract: Investors worry new controls may be in the offing as a news report says the Justice Department may bring charges by the end of the year.

title: No Laptop, No Phone, No Desk: UBS Reinvents the Work Space
abstract: The bulk of UBS’s employees will no longer have a fixed desk at its new building in London as the Swiss bank embraces a more mobile work environment.

title: New York Area Has the Nation’s 3 Worst Airports, Study Says
abstract: A travel website’s examination of timeliness, accessibility and amenities at the United States’ 30 busiest airports found fault with La Guardia, J.F.K. and Newark.

title: The Paris Agreement on Climate Change Is Official. Now What?
abstract: Top energy policy makers and corporate leaders say it will be challenging to meet even the deal’s modest goals to reduce emissions and greenhouse gases.

title: Former Napa Valley Winemaker Arrested in Fraud Scheme
abstract: A grand jury charged Jeffry James Hill with stealing grapes and deceiving customers about the source and type of grapes in the wines he sold.

title: Credit Suisse’s Cost-Cutting Is Hindered by Rising Risks
abstract: Profitability is under pressure in Credit Suisse’s wealth management and trading businesses.

title: Why Washington Needs Wall Street
abstract: Many government jobs could be filled by someone with a Wall Street background to the benefit of the American people.

title: Daily Report: A New Helper in the Virtual Assistant Race
abstract: Google will introduce Home, its rival to Amazon’s Alexa, at the end of this week.

title: Make Siri Hear You on a Mac Mini
abstract: Not every Mac model comes with a microphone, but you can still command Apple’s virtual assistant with an external accessory.

title: Google Rebuts Antitrust Claims in Europe
abstract: The search giant faces three cases accusing it of hampering consumer choice and crippling competitors, all of which it denies.

title: Wall St. Closes Lower as Election Looms
abstract: Shares of Fitbit and Facebook were lower on concerns about the companies’ growth outlooks.

title: How Economic Data Is Kept Politics-Free
abstract: Despite what partisans may say, career civil servants who compile employment reports follow ground rules that undermine claims that the results are rigged.

title: Google Home vs. Amazon Echo: A Face-Off of Smart Speakers
abstract: Which is a better helper, Google Home or Amazon Echo? A side-by-side test for six days revealed strengths and weaknesses.

title: Morning Agenda: Fed Holds Steady, Teaming Up or Divesting?
abstract: The Federal Reserve decided not to raise rates, but struck a more positive note than in September. Why all the indecision?

title: A Rare Moment of Unity on Capitol Hill, Thanks to Trump’s Taxes
abstract: Revelations that Donald J. Trump paid no federal income tax for years, or decades, have energized bipartisan efforts to overhaul the loophole-ridden tax code.

title: Big Question on Climate Crisis: How to Inspire Innovation
abstract: The world’s governments have committed to slashing greenhouse emissions, but it is not clear the necessary technology exists yet.

title: Big Oil Slowly Adapts to a Warming World
abstract: Major oil and gas companies, facing future loss of demand for their products as a result of climate change policies, search for new strategies.

title: Batteries That Make Use of Solar Power, Even in the Dark
abstract: Solar farms are increasingly common, but they depend on the sun. A new technology harvests that energy so it can be sold when prices are high.

title: ‘Everyone Needs to Act’: What to Expect From Climate Talks in Morocco
abstract: Ahead of the global climate change conference, four experts explain why it is an important, if less momentous, follow-up to Paris.

title: Pollution Accord Is Set for Global Flights, but Tasks Remain
abstract: The new agreement for world aviation aims to cap greenhouse gas emissions, but doubts emerge about the plan’s use of complex offsetting credits.

title: Why Light Bulbs May Be the Next Hacker Target
abstract: Wireless “smart” devices may be the tech wave of the future, but researchers have found flaws that let hackers spread malicious code through them.

title: A Global Climate Deal Was Reached. Next Up Is Pollution Monitoring.
abstract: The new phase of turning agreements into a real reduction of emissions starts on Monday at the next major United Nations climate change summit conference.

title: Energy Giants Turn to Drones and Sensors in New Embrace of the Digital World
abstract: Amid continuing low oil and natural gas prices, companies are again turning to tech advances to cut costs, raise productivity and expand exploration.

title: Renewable Energy Grows in an Unlikely Place: the Sunny Mideast
abstract: The Middle East, long a bastion of oil and gas production, is moving toward solar power.

title: At Trader Joe’s, Good Cheer May Hide Complaints
abstract: Some workers at Trader Joe’s stores, including one who says he was fired for lacking a “genuine” smile, have complained about their treatment and of safety lapses.

title: Wells Fargo Faces Scrutiny for Black Marks on Ex-Employee Files
abstract: Three senators asked for data on forms filed by the bank, which former employees say contained negative comments as retaliation against whistle-blowers.

title: Fox News Lineup Begins to Take Shape
abstract: Tucker Carlson will take over the prime-time anchor slot once held by Greta van Susteren, starting Nov. 14.

title: You Might Be Paying Too Much for Your Chicken
abstract: Investors contend that the way a chicken pricing index used by grocery stores is compiled has kept the retail price of chicken artificially high.
